title-group.article-title: Update of a systematic review on associations between environmental exposures and asthma control and exacerbations in young children

contrib-group.aff: 1Child Health, University of Aberdeen, Aberdeen, UK
2Child Health, University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust, Birmingham, UK

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: To update our previous systematic review of the literature and describe associations published since 2014 between environmental exposure and asthma control and exacerbations in children.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: Systematic literature review following the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses guidelines.

sec.title: Data sources
sec.p: The search strategy from our earlier review was used to search the following databases: MEDLINE/OVID (1946–Present), Embase/OVID SP (1980–Present), CINAHL, Cochrane Centre Trials Register (CCTR), Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews and Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE). Searches were carried out on 5 November 2021 and updated on 3 April 2023. Literature published since 2014 until the date of the search was included.

sec.title: Eligibility criteria
sec.p: Studies that examined the association between environmental exposures and asthma exacerbations in children. Study participants were children with a mean age of ≤9 years. Outcomes of interest were indices of asthma symptoms, control and exacerbations. We included systematic reviews, intervention studies, time series and time-stratified case crossover studies and longitudinal cohort studies.

sec.title: Data extraction and synthesis
sec.p: Four researchers independently screened full text articles in English for inclusion and assessed them for quality using the Effective Public Health Practice Project Quality assessment tool. A meta-analysis was carried out for a subgroup of selected papers.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were 20 339 papers screened and 110 were eligible, including 23 rated strong, 81 rated medium and 6 low quality. There were 17 systematic reviews and 7 randomised controlled trials (RCTs). In most observational studies, exposure to exhaled tobacco smoke or respiratory virus and increasing exposures to outdoor air pollutants (including particulate matter, nitrogen dioxide, traffic-related air pollution and dust storms), fungal spores or tree pollen were associated with increased risk of worsening asthma outcomes. RCTs to reduce indoor air exposures were done in small populations and, although often able to reduce exposures, only one intervention changed asthma outcomes.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The number of eligible papers has increased to 110 from 27 described in our 2014 review, and the quality of papers has also increased. While associations between exposures and worsening outcomes are increasingly consistent, what remains unclear is whether interventions, particularly for indoor air and diet, may improve outcomes.

caption.title: Strengths and limitations of this study

list-item.p: We used the same methodology as our earlier review, published in 2014, and this allowed us to compare how the literature has changed in the interim period.
A second strength is that our search strategy identified 95% of original studies that were also identified in 16 eligible systematic reviews.
By using our earlier methodology, we were limited to studying the same exposures and the same age group (mean age: ≤9 years old).
Another limitation of this work is that due to heterogeneity of study design, we were limited in the exposures where we were able to undertake meta-analysis for outdoor air pollution exposures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Asthma is a common condition among children and young people; the prevalence of asthma symptoms worldwide was reported to be 9.1% for children and 11% for adolescents.1 The goal of asthma treatment is for the child to have controlled symptoms and no asthma exacerbations.2 Asthma control is determined by asthma symptoms and need for reliever medication.2 Asthma exacerbations cause morbidity, and occasionally mortality, and lead to unscheduled healthcare activity, loss of days at school for children and days off work for their parents and carers.3

Reviews of the literature published in 2014 (by our group) and in 2015 have described exposures associated with asthma exacerbations4 5 and loss of asthma control.4 Our aim was to repeat the methodology in our previous review4 in order to describe how the evidence has changed in the intervening years. A consequence of using our earlier methodology4 was that we were obliged to focus on the age group and exposures previously described.

sec.title: Protocol and registration
sec.p: The study protocol followed the methodology of the Centre of Reviews for Dissemination (CRD) and the study was registered with PROSPERO (CRD42021290184; PROSPERO (york.ac.uk)).

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: Environmental exposures were determined at workshops involving senior researchers from government and academia, health practitioners and policy professionals but not patients.4

sec.title: Search strategy and data sources
sec.p: We used the search strategy from the previous review4 (online supplemental material), starting from the date of our previous search, i.e. January 2013, until date of search. We did not include papers from the previous review.4 The search was first run on 5 November 2021 and subsequently on 3 April 2023. The following databases were searched—MEDLINE/OVID (1946–Present), Embase/ OVID SP (1980–Present), CINAHL, Cochrane Centre Trials Register (CCTR), Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews and Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE).

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: Meta-analyses, systematic reviews, randomised controlled trials (RCTs), non-RCTs or cohort studies were sought; where none were identified, cross-sectional studies (including panel studies), case–control and case-report studies were included.6 A study was eligible if the study population had a stated mean age ≤9 years.

Articles not published in English language, or which were letters, abstracts or conference proceedings were ineligible. Clinical trials of medications were also excluded, including vitamin supplements.

sec.title: Environmental exposures
sec.p: We included studies which related these previously determined environmental exposures4 to asthma outcomes:

list-item.p: Outdoor air quality (including traffic fumes, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), chlorine, phthalates, sulphur dioxide and ozone). As there is a well-recognised correlation between products of burning fossil fuels, we focused on particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2). Our previous review did not separately consider papers that considered exposure to a) traffic-related air pollution (TRAP, proximity to roads as distinct to specific chemical exposures) and b) dust storms, but these were considered separately here.
Inhaled allergens (house dust mite, pets and pollens).
Domestic combustion (gas, solid fuel and candles).
Air conditioning and humidifiers (including high efficiency vacuum cleaners).

sec.title: Study outcomes
sec.p: The primary outcomes were asthma exacerbations or asthma control in childhood.

list-item.p: Child: As previously, we focused on children with a stated mean age of ≤9 years.4 Where no mean age was provided, we included data from individuals aged <18 years.
Asthma exacerbation: Defined per each study protocol, typically prescription of oral corticosteroids and/or ED or hospitalisation for asthma symptoms.
Asthma control: Defined as a symptom score, for example, Children’s Asthma Control Test.

sec.title: Study selection
sec.p: Results were exported into a systematic review management software.7 After deduplication, each title and abstract was scanned by two of the four researchers (SD, RD, MG and SS), and any differences were resolved following discussion with the fifth author (ST). Full texts of selected papers were obtained and scanned by two of the four authors (SD, RD, MG and SS) to identify papers for inclusion in the review. Where there was a disagreement, two of the authors (SD and ST) met to agree on the final decision. We also scanned reference lists of the selected papers for relevant articles. Reasons for exclusion were documented.

sec.title: Data collection process
sec.p: Data were extracted on preagreed outcome variables based on the population, intervention, comparator and outcome elements for each included study according to Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) reporting items checklist (http://www.prisma-statement.org/documents/PRISMA_2020_checklist.pdf) by four reviewers (SD, RD, MG and SS).

sec.title: Quality assessment
sec.p: Eligible papers were assessed for their quality using the same tool as used in our previous review4 (Effective Public Health Practice Project Quality assessment tool for quantitative studies (https://www.ephpp.ca/quality-assessment-tool-for-quantitative-studies/) by two of the four authors (SD, RD, MG and SS) and categorised as strong, moderate and weak. This tool takes into consideration selection bias, use of appropriate study design, methodological aspects such as confounding factors, blinding, data collection methods, completeness of reporting, intervention integrity and analyses. Where there was a difference of opinion, the lower of the two scores was accepted as final. The systematic reviews included in this review were assessed for quality using the Critical Appraisals Skills Programme checklist for systematic reviews (Critical Appraisal Skills Programme (casp-uk.net)).

sec.title: Summary measures
sec.p: The outcome measures were number of days of asthma symptoms, number of children attending ED or being hospitalisalised expressed as ORs, relative risk (RR) or mean difference.

sec.title: Synthesis of results
sec.p: Data from papers were tabulated as recommended by the PRISMA reporting items checklist (https://prisma-statement.org//prismastatement/Checklist.aspx). Based on the heterogeneity identified within the included studies in relation to factors such as study design, settings and risk of bias, a narrative synthesis was undertaken using the Synthesis Without Meta-Analysis Guidelines.8 The studies were grouped based on the various environmental exposures as determined during our previous review4; however, due to the heterogeneity in the study designs, effect direction plots9 were created to understand the association between exposures and outcomes where there were more than two studies. A meta-analysis was performed using standard software (RevMan V5.4) for a subgroup of studies on exposure to particulate matter and Nitrogen dioxide (NO2) using both random and fixed effects models where appropriate; funnel plots were used to evaluate potential for publication bias.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We identified 20 339 studies of which 110 studies were included in this review (figure 1). Table 1 compares the number of studies eligible, including their study design, with the studies included in our 2014 review.4 No studies were identified for vacuuming.

caption.title: Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses flow diagram.
A comparison between the number of studies identified for the various environmental exposures in the current and earlier review

fn.p: Includes traffic fumes, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), chlorine, phthalates, sulfur dioxide, ozone. In the present review we found the following number of eligible papers for exposures where we did not identify any papers in our earlier review: traffic-related air pollution n=8; dust storms and fireworks and bonfires n=6; VOCs, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and phthalates =7.

sec.p: Characteristics of included studies are presented in online supplemental table S1. We identified 17 systematic reviews (which included a total of 527 studies) (online supplemental table S1). Of the 479 studies included in 16 of these systematic reviews, our search strategy had identified 457 (95%). Results from the quality assessment of the included studies are presented in online supplemental tables S3 and S4. Based on the available data, where meta-analyses were not possible, effect direction plots for exposures were created (online supplemental figure S1). Where cross-sectional and case–control studies were identified for exposures but where other studies with more robust designs were available, details were not included in the main results table but are available in the supplement (online supplemental table S5).

sec.title: Environmental tobacco smoke
sec.p: One systematic review,10 one RCT,11 four cohort studies1215 and one non-randomised study16 were identified. Ratings for quality were strong for two studies,10 13 moderate for four studies11 12 14 16 and weak for one.15 The systematic review (434 737 children in 25 studies)10 found that OR for being admitted to hospital with asthma were higher for children exposed to ETS compared to the non-exposed children (OR 1.85, 95% CI 1.20 to 2.86, p=0.01). The RCT11 recruited 222 participants who were randomised to either intervention (n=107) with home-based asthma follow-up and environmental control educational programme carried out by nurse specialists or standard care (n=115). Exposure to ETS was determined by salivary cotinine levels. There was no difference in exposure between intervention and control groups and no difference in asthma ED visits for exposed compared with unexposed children (HR 1.10, 95% CL 0.76 to 1.69 p=0.61).

Among the cohort studies, Andrews et al12 reported a relationship between reported ETS exposure and length of hospital stay (LOS) for asthma exacerbation (mean LOS 50 hours, 95% CI 47 to 54) compared with a non-ETS-exposed control group (mean LOS 46 hours, 95% CI 43 to 48) (p=0.02). Additionally, within their cohort of 623 children, those exposed to ETS experienced higher odds for a hospital admission (OR 1.5, 95% CI 1.0 to 2.3). A cohort of 767 children with an asthma admission found no association between home ETS exposure and subsequent readmission or Emergency Departmnet (ED) visit.13 One cohort study14 followed up 671 children after hospitalisation for an asthma exacerbation and found no association between salivary cotinine levels during hospitalisation and the risk of subsequent asthma-related ED attendance.

A fourth cohort study of 101 children with an asthma admission reported an association between maternal-reported smoking and future asthma exacerbations (Incidence Rate Ratio (IRR) 3.12, 95% CI 1.12 to 8.68).15 Results for a non-randomised study where ETS and other exposures were modified16 are discussed under ‘Multiple exposures’.

sec.title: Particulate matter (PM2.5, PM10) and NO2
sec.p: 61 studies were identified. There were seven systematic reviews,1723 of which four were rated strong17 19 22 23 and three were moderate.18 20 21 Six of the seven reviews reported a positive association between exposure to particulate matter and NO2 and asthma-related ED visits and/or admissions (table 2).

caption.title: Results from systematic reviews on exposure to PM2.5 or PM10 or NO2 and Asthma exacerbations expressed as ED visits/hospital admissions

tr.th: Unit of exposure associated with outcome
Each 10 µg/m3 PM2.5 increase and ED attendance and/or hospitalisationOR or RR (95% CI)
Each 10 µg/m3 PM10 increase and ED attendance and/or hospitalisationOR or RR (95% CI)
Each 10 µg/m3 or 10 ppb NO2 increase and ED attendance and/or hospitalisationOR or RR (95% CI)

fn.p: ED, Emergency Department; NO2, nitrogen dioxide; PM2.5, particulate matter 2.5; RR, relative risk.

sec.p: The seventh systematic review19 (eight studies) conducted a meta-analysis and reported an association between increasing exposure to ultrafine particles (10 000 particles/cm3) in children <18 years of age and risk of ED visits (OR 1.11, 95% CI 1.06 to 1.17), hospitalisation for asthma (OR 1.05, 95% CI 1.00 to 1.09), asthma exacerbations (OR 1.07, 95% CI 1.04 to 1.10) and exacerbations at long lags (lag days 2–6) (OR 1.06, 95% CI 1.04 to 1.08).

In addition to these 7 systematic reviews, there were 54 other eligible studies, including 25 that included PM, two including NO2 and 27 including both (online supplemental table S1). 17 were time series studies,2440 20 were time stratified case cross-over analyses,4160 16 were cohort studies6176 and 1 non-randomised study.77 Ratings for QA were strong for one,69 moderate for 49,246870 71 73 77 and weak for four.727476 Of these 54 studies, 35243234 reported a significant association between an IQR increase of 8–13 µg/m3 in PM2.5 and/or PM10 and ED visits/hospitalisation for asthma (OR/Risk ratio between 1.01 and 3.2).

A positive association between increasing exposures to NO2 and increased odds/risk ratio for ED visits/hospitalisation was observed in nine time series studies,2426 3135 37 38 six time series case-crossover studies41 42 47 51 54 59 and two cohort studies.64 68 ORs/risk ratios were between 1.02 and 2.7 per IQR increase of 5–18 ppb NO2.

There were studies where researchers found no link between exposure to PM2.5 and/or PM10,26 33 56 62 66 67 or NO2,66 67 73 and odds or risk of asthma exacerbations or asthma symptoms. In one study, exposure to increasing PM2.5 increments was associated with a reduced risk of ED visits for asthma after an interval of 7 days (RR per 10 µg/m3 0.961, 95% CI 0.932 to 0.991).38

sec.title: Meta-analyses
sec.p: Meta-analyses were carried out for studies not included in the previous seven reviews. Where results were given for different age groups and with different lags, results from 0 to 18 years and those with the most positive association were included. There were consistent associations between IQR increases in PM2.5 and PM10 and ED attendance (see figure 2), less consistent associations between increases in PM2.5 and PM10 and hospitalisation (see figure 3) and no association between NO2 exposure and outcomes (table 3). There was a positive association between 10 µg/m3 increments of PM2.5 and hospitalisation (online supplemental figure S2). There was evidence of publication bias for associations between 10 µg/m3 increments of PM2.5 and Emergency Department attendance, and asthma admission (online supplemental figure S3).

caption.title: Forest plots showing pooled ORs for risk of ED visits following interquartile rising exposure to (A) Particulate Matter2.5 (B) Particulate Matter10 and (C) Nitrogen Dioxide.
Forest plots showing pooled ORs for risk of Hospitalisations following interquartile rising exposures to (A) Particulate Matter2.5 (B) Particulate Matter10 and (C) Nitrogen Dioxide
Results from meta-analyses of studies on exposure to PM2.5, PM10 and NO2 and risk of asthma-related ED visits or hospital admissions

tr.td: Too small, big differences between studies
Too small, big differences between studies

fn.p: ED, Emergency Department; NO2, nitrogen dioxide; PM10, Particulate Matter with diameter <10 microns; PM2.5, Particulate Matter with diameter <2.5 microns.

sec.title: Traffic-related air pollution
sec.p: There were eight longitudinal studies of which one was rated strong,78 six medium1469 7982 and one weak.83

Five studies reported positive associations between proximity to major traffic routes and asthma-related ED visits or hospitalisation. In one study of 329 children with wheeze or asthma,78 those living within 500 m of a factory, highway or urban expressway were at increased risk of an asthma exacerbation (OR 1.79, 95% CI 1.13 to 2.84). A second study of 350 children with asthma living in inner cities83 found that asthma symptom days reduced for each additional 100 m a child lived away from major roadways (OR 0.71, 95% CI 0.58 to 0.87). In a third study of 17 084 children,69 those living within 2.5km radius of a major roadway and those living within 400m radius of " individual PM2.5 sources" had more asthma-related ED visits and hospitalisations ()R 3.06, 95% CI 2.84, 3.30; OR 1.33, 95% CI 1.25 to 1.41), respectively. A fourth study80 reported increased risk of an asthma-related ED visit for children living within <100 m of a major roadway, compared with those living >300 m away (OR 1.08, 95% CI 1.03 to 1.13). A fifth study82 described how children living 5–10 miles from a railyard had higher odds of ED visits (OR 1.18, 95% CI 1.13 to 1.23) and those living 20–25 miles away had reduced odds (OR 0.94, 95% CI 0.90 to 0.98), compared with those living 10–20 miles away.
Three studies which included a total of 7637 children found no association between TRAP and asthma exacerbations.14 79 81

sec.title: Dust storms
sec.p: Five studies were identified, including one time series study84 and four time stratified case crossover studies (where patients acted as their own control).48 63 85 86 Quality rating was moderate for all five. In the time series study,84 there were increased asthma admissions among ≤6 year olds one (β=5.66, 95% CI 1.88 to 9.44, p=0.003) and three days after a storm (β=6.37, 95% CI 2.16 to 10.59, p=0.003), but not after two days, compared with non-storm days. In one time stratified case crossover study,85 there was an association between dust storm and increased asthma-related ED visits after an interval of three (OR 1.84, 95% CI 1.21 to 2.79) and four days (OR 1.83, 95% CI 1.18 to 2.81) compared with a week before the exposure. A second crossover study from Japan86 reported an increased self-reported asthma symptoms on the day of a dust storm (HR 5.17, 95% CI 1.02 to 26.12). The third crossover study from Guadeloupe63 reported the risk of ED visits for asthma was higher among 498 children aged 5–8 years on the 52 days with dust present (excess risk percentage 5.9% (95% CI 5.0% to 7.2%)) compared with non-dust days (excess risk percentage 1.7%, (95% CI –0.1% to –4.4%)). In the fourth case crossover study of children aged 0–9 years from South Korea,48 there was no relationship between asthma-related hospital visits and dust exposure.

sec.title: Fireworks and bonfires
sec.p: The one eligible cohort study,87 rated moderate for quality, found no increase in asthma-related ED visits or hospitalisations after wildfires in 2003 (n=2195 children) and 2007 (n=3965 children), but there was increased prescribing of short acting β-agonists after the fires in 2003; the highest increase was in obese children (OR 1.42, 95% CI 1.12 to 1.80).

sec.title: VOCs, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and phthalates
sec.p: We identified one systematic review,88 two time series studies,28 89 two time stratified case crossover studies,90 91 one non-randomised study92 and one cohort study.93 Three studies were rated as moderate,9092 and the rest were rated as strong.

The systematic review (9 papers, 387 children)88 related exposure to swimming pools and asthma outcomes. In a narrative synthesis based on data from seven studies, the authors concluded that swimming was associated with a reduction in asthma attacks and improvement in asthma symptoms but could not describe which exposures related to swimming contributed to this association.

A time series study28 found an association between each 10 ng/m3 increase in PM2.5-bound polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and asthma-related ED visits, 1 (RR 1.58, 95% CI 1.37 to 1.81) and 2 days after increased exposure (RR 1.43, 95% CI 1.27 to 1.61). The second time series study89 found that the transition of the local electricity generating power plant from coal to natural gas was associated with a decrease in mean monthly rate of asthma visits (RR 0.63, 95% CI 0.58 to 0.69, p<0.001).

A time-stratified case crossover study reported in two publications90 91 described an association between exposure to methyl bromide (OR 1.07, 95% CI 1.02 to 1.13) and 1–3-dichloropropene (OR 1.14, 95% CI 1.09 to 1.2) and risk of ED visits for asthma in children 6–18 years of age.

One non-randomised study92 reported increased asthma admissions after the opening of an unconventional natural gas development (UNGD) (OR 1.19, 95% CI 1.04 to 1.36) for children of all ages and (OR 1.35, 95% CI 1.14 to 1.60) for 2–6 years compared with populations with no UNGD activity. A second paper by the same group93 found that, compared with no drilling activity, both conventional natural gas development and UNGD were associated with increased asthma hospitalisations (OR 1.23 (95% CI 1.13 to 1.34) and 1.59 (95% CI 1.46 to 1.73), respectively).

sec.title: Damp housing and mould
sec.p: One RCT94 rated strong for quality and two non-randomised studies16 95 rated moderate for quality examined the effect of damp housing and mould and how it affects asthma outcomes. These studies investigated multiple exposures and are included under ‘multiple risk factors.’

sec.title: Inhaled allergens
sec.p: The search identified 17 studies, 1 systematic review,96 3 RCTs,9799 and 11 time series and case crossover studies,2531 40 41 43 44 100105 and 2 cohort studies.68 106 The quality rating for seven studies was strong419698 100 and was moderate for the remainder.25 31 40 43 44 68 99 104 106

The systematic review96 (14 studies) examined exposure to outdoor pollen and the risk of ED attendance for asthma, and meta-analysis of data from three studies found no association between 10 unit increases in grass pollen grains/m3 and the mean number of asthma-related ED admissions.

One RCT97 intervened with house dust impermeable bedding for 117 mite-sensitised children aged 3–17 years who had been admitted to hospital with an asthma exacerbation. Compared with 106 controls, the intervention reduced HDM exposure 12 months postintervention and with reduced asthma-related ED visits (HR 0.55, 95% CI 0.36 to 0.85). A second RCT98 intervened in 41 schools with either an integrated pest management (IPM) programme for a year and/or high efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filter purifiers for two weeks. Children with asthma were randomised into four groups (59 in each; IPM and HEPA; IPM and sham HEPA; No IPM and HEPA; No IPM and sham HEPA). The intervention reduced mouse (β −0.54, 95% CI −0.88 to −0.19) and dog allergen exposure but not the number of symptom days. The third RCTl99 randomised children with poorly controlled asthma to an intervention of education and HEPA air cleaners in the bedroom and living rooms (n=36) or education alone (n=34). After 12 months, the intervention was associated with reduced risk for symptoms in the past 2 weeks (IRR 0.71 (95% CI 0.52 to 0.98)) and reduced risk for unplanned healthcare use (IRR 0.35 (95% CI 0.13 to 0.94)).

There were 11 time series case studies describing the relation between pollen counts and asthma-related ED visits or hospitalisations. One study100 measured admissions during two pollen seasons and found increased OR for ED admission in association with rising pollen counts: Alternaria (OR=1.01 conidia/m3 95% CI 1.00 to 1.03), weed (OR=1.07 per count/m3 95% CI 1.00 to 1.01) and tree (OR=1.00 per count/m3 95% CI 1.00 to 1.01). A second study40 described a positive association between several pollen species and ED presentations, for example, urticaceae (lag 0 HR=1.02, 95% CI 1.01 to 1.03). A third study101 compared low (≤5 grains/m) and high exposure to tree pollen (>1000 grains/m3) to no exposure and found both were associated with asthma exacerbations (OR 1.06 (95% CI 1.02 to 1.10) and 1.64 (95% CI 1.45 to 1.84), respectively). A fourth study102 reported an association between spring pollen exposures and increased ED visits (OR 1.7, 95% CI 1.5 to 1.9). A fifth study103 reported an association between increasing pollen exposure and hospitalisations, for example, for grass pollen OR=1.037 (95% CI 1.005 to 1.070). A sixth study41 reported an association between rising total pollen count and hospitalisations (5-day cumulative effect per 10 grains/m3) (OR 1.04, 95% CI 1.02 to 1.06).

Results from two time series studies43 44 found increasing exposure to tree pollen was associated with an increased risk ratio for ED visits (RR 1.08, 95% CI 1.06 to 1.10). A ninth study31 found exposure to tree (grains/m3) and weed (grains/m3) pollen was associated with increased odds for ED visit (lag 0 RR per quartile rise 1.014, 95% CI 1.004 to 1.118, p<0.05 and lag 0 RR 1.040, 95% CI 1.009 to 1.072, p<0.05), respectively. The ninth time series study25 reported a positive correlation between outdoor Alternaria spores and ED visits for asthma (β 0.0081 (SE 0.0004), p<0.01).

A time-stratified case crossover analysis105 found a relationship between total outdoor fungal spore concentrations and increased odds for asthma hospitalisations, independent of rhinovirus infection (aOR 1.05; 95% CI 1.01 to 1.09); similar aORs were also seen for exposures to Alternaria, Leptosphaeria, Coprinus and Drechslera species. A second publication by the same group104 reported an association between increasing outdoor total fungal spore concentrations over five years and increased childhood asthma hospitalisations (OR 1.02, 95% CI 1.00 to 1.03, p<0.05).

A cohort study106 evaluated the association between aeroallergen exposures in schools and the asthma symptoms in 351 children, adjusted for home exposures. Exposure to the 75th percentile of mouse allergen (3.84 µg/g) in school dust compared with 25th percentile (0.23 µg/g) was associated with increased asthma-related symptom days (OR 1.27 95% CI 1.05 to 1.54, p=0.02). The second cohort study68 found a correlation between grass pollen count over a 12-month period and ED admissions for children aged <16 years (p<0.001).

sec.title: Domestic combustion
sec.p: We identified one systematic review (13 studies),107 rated moderate for quality, which included meta-analysis of twelve studies and which found no association between indoor wood burning and childhood asthma admissions.

sec.title: Industrial combustion
sec.p: A retrospective cohort study from South Korea,108 rated moderate for quality, reported that children living <2 km away from the incinerators had an increased risk of asthma-related hospitalisation (RR 1.12, 95% CI 1.08 to 1.17) compared with those living 2–5 km away (RR 0.99, 95% CI 0.97 to 1.02).

sec.title: Air conditioning and humidifiers
sec.p: We identified two RCTs94 109 where intervention consisted of using either HEPA cleaners or ventilators. Multiple environmental exposures were considered as discussed under ‘multiple exposures.’

sec.title: Dietary exposures
sec.p: Two systematic reviews110 111 and one RCT112 were identified. One systematic review110 was rated strong and the other two studies111 112 were rated moderate for quality assessment.

The first systematic review111 included 12 studies of which 10 examined the relationship between adherence to a Mediterranean diet (rich in vitamins, fibre, minerals and fatty acids) and asthma outcomes; the remaining two studies had allergic rhinitis as the outcome. Seven of the 10 studies found an apparent protective role of the Mediterranean diet on asthma severity and control in children (n=3721); the magnitude of effect was not presented. A second systematic review110 linked Mediterranean diet to asthma symptoms and identified 15 studies (78 165 children), of which 12 found a Mediterranean diet was associated with reduced odds for asthma outcomes (OR between 0.55 and 0.97).
One RCT112 found no difference in exacerbations between 33 children randomised to an intervention where Australian Dietary Guidelines were met and 34 who received no intervention.

sec.title: Respiratory viral infections
sec.p: There was one systematic review,113 one observational study114 and two time series studies.31 115 One study was rated as strong for quality,114 with the others being moderate quality. In two studies, the presence of virus was detected by testing the nasopharyngeal swabs.114 115

The systematic review included 28 papers113 and only one paper showed a significant association between Human Rhinovirus and asthma exacerbation severity (mean score, exposed patients 10.4, 95% CI 10.0 to 10.9 vs non-exposed patients 9.4, 95% CI 8.7 to 10.2; p=0.016).

In an observational study embedded within a 16 week pharmacological RCT,114 nasal secretions were collected when 27 children were symptomatic of an upper respiratory tract infection (but not necessarily an asthma exacerbation) and 20 had virus detected, with the authors concluding that most viral infections did not result in asthma exacerbations.

In a time series study,31 HRV and influenza virus (IFV), determined using weekly national respiratory tract virus detection rates, were associated with asthma-related ED visits on lag day 5 (HRV RR 1.042, 95% CI 1.012 to 1.076; IFV RR 1.038, 95% CI 1.016 to 1.064).

In another time series study,115 nasopharyngeal swabs from 532 asthma-related ED visits were tested for influenza during an epidemic. There was a positive correlation (r>0.5) between the number of asthma exacerbations (ED visits for asthma) and the number of samples positive for influenza on day 0 of the influenza epidemic.

sec.title: COVID-19
sec.p: One exceedingly small retrospective cohort study was identified,116 rated moderate quality. This reported severe asthma defined by severity of symptoms and use of controller medications was more likely among the 10 children with asthma testing positive compared with the 6 who were COVID-negative (p=0.016).

sec.title: Multiple risk factors
sec.p: We identified three systematic reviews, two RCTs and three non-randomised studies which related multiple exposures to asthma outcomes.1694 95 109 117120 Rating for QA was strong for three94 109 118 and moderate for five papers.16 95 117 119 120

A systematic review117 identified 35 studies which described interactions between outdoor allergens (pollen, fungal spores) and air pollutants and any respiratory outcomes (including asthma outcomes). There was evidence of interaction from small experimental observational studies, and the magnitude of association was small, and the authors attributed this to exposure misclassification, failure to examine subgroups at risk, inadequate statistical power or absence of population-level effects.

A second systematic review118 identified 26 community-based interventions delivered to children with asthma, four of which were RCTs. Three RCTs and seventeen non-RCT studies reported reduced asthma-related ED visits and/or hospitalisations associated with the intervention. Interventions around policy (smoke free laws), environmental change (green housing initiatives) and care coordination (nurse-delivered care, working with families, home visits and education) were most effective.

Third systematic review119 of 12 RCTs (including 2719 participants) which delivered complex interventions to children with asthma, including asthma education, home interventions to reduce asthma triggers and improve medication adherence. In six RCTs, the intervention was associated with reduced asthma hospitalisations (mean difference in number of hospitalisations between 0.10 and 1.36). The authors observed that interventions with multiple components, such as educational elements, reducing home environmental asthma triggers and regular follow-up, were more effective than those with one or two components.

In one RCT,94 researchers intervened with domestic heat recovery ventilators (intervention n=43 homes) compared with energy recovery ventilators (control n=40 homes) among young children and described asthma symptoms as the outcome. The intervention reduced airborne mould spores and VOC exposure (including formaldehyde) but was not associated with a change in days with asthma symptoms, ED visits or hospitalisations over 12 months.

In another RCT,109 9 intervention classrooms with 12 children with asthma received HEPA cleaners, and 9 control classrooms with 13 children with asthma received sham cleaners. Some of the intervention classrooms also received Integrated Pest Management. The intervention resulted in significant reductions in PM2.5 and black carbon concentrations but not in allergen levels, and there were no differences in the number of children reporting asthma symptoms between the groups.

In a non-randomised study,120 children with ‘not well’ or ‘very poorly’ controlled asthma aged 3–17 years old received either a standard community health worker (CHW) education programme (n=68) or CHW programme plus diagnostic home air tightness measurements, combustion safety testing, heating system assessment and assessment of moisture-related problems (n=38). There was no difference in exposure to indoor smoking or ED attendance between groups. Asthma control improved in both groups, with 71% in the intervention group becoming fully controlled compared with 48% in the control group, p=0.04.

A non-randomised study described how asthma symptoms changed after the introduction of a home-based education programme for reducing asthma triggers such as exposure to ETS and included physical home interventions such as mould reduction and pest control.16 The intervention was associated with reduced mean (SD) asthma symptom-days over the 2 weeks before 5.01 (4.27) and after introduction 2.66 (3.86), p<0.01, and a reduction in mean (SD) asthma-related ED visits over 3 months from 1.17 (3.06) to 0.50 (0.67), p<0.01.

A second non-randomised before -and-after study95 introduced an intervention with asthma education, including management of asthma triggers such as damp, mould, pet and pest allergens and HDM, to 218 families. The intervention was associated with a reduction in asthma admissions (pre 16% vs post 5%, p<0.0001) and ED visits (pre 47% vs post 24%, p<0.0001), but not in objectively measured asthma triggers.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present review describes associations between environmental exposures and asthma outcomes in children identified in papers published between 2014 and 2024. Many exposures, including ETS, TRAP, dust storms, VOCs, damp housing and mould and inhaled allergens, were associated with adverse asthma outcomes, see effect direction plots (online supplemental figures S1a–S1f). The associations described do not prove causation; many identified RCTs did not alter exposures, and when they did, asthma outcomes were usually not improved.

There remains a need for effective interventions to be designed prior to being tested in RCTs. Another consideration for researchers designing interventions is that multifaceted interventions may have greater impact on improving asthma outcomes compared with simpler interventions.118 119

Repeating our earlier methodology4 allowed us to directly compare how the literature has changed since 2014. For ETS exposure, there is a higher quality of data linking exposure to asthma outcomes, an objective measure of exposure is more commonly used, but the magnitude of the association is smaller than previously,4 with three studies finding no association between exposures and hospital admission.11 13 14

Since our previous review,4 there has been a marked rise in the number of outdoor air pollution-related publications, and this is a broader area which now includes TRAP and dust storms. While many observational studies find associations with exposures and asthma outcomes, the lag between exposure and outcome varies. Multipollutant models do not always identify the same individual exposure as being the dominant adverse exposure, and a substantial number of studies find no evidence of association. Similar to our earlier review,4 the literature describing associations between asthma outcomes and exposures to domestic and industrial combustion and diet remains limited, and even for the Mediterranean diet (for which there was a high quality systematic review) associations were not consistent.

The literature describing links between damp housing and mould exposure to asthma outcomes is much more extensive than the one RCT and one observational study in our earlier review.4 Of all exposures considered in this review, the evidence for causation is strongest here with intervention in two of the three RCTs improving asthma outcomes.

Modifying outdoor air exposures is not amenable to RCT methodology.121 There is proof of concept that modification of domestic environmental exposures can lessen the burden of morbidity and mortality from asthma experienced (Murray et al)97 and for other exposures, for example outdoor air, the Bradford-Hill criteria121 can be used to determine whether association with exposure and asthma outcomes is by causation.

Despite the relatively large number of papers with moderate-to-good quality identified in our review, the literature has some limitations. For example, associations are often inconsistent between studies both in terms of their presence and their nature, for example, different lag between air pollutant exposure and symptoms. We have also identified evidence of some publication bias in the air pollution literature papers, and this bias may be present elsewhere in the literature. Description of confounding factors and use of data collection methods was not always adequately provided in some observational studies, especially those which investigated multiple environments and inhaled exposures as a combination of allergens, moulds and viruses.

There are a number of weaknesses in our review methodology which should be considered when interpreting our results. First, as with all systematic reviews, we are aware that some potentially eligible studies have been missed, but our search identified 95% of individual papers cited in systematic review papers. Second, for air pollution, we considered only PM and NO2 as exposures, since other products of fossil fuel combustion, for example, SO2, CO and ozone are positively correlated with PM25 39 40 56 67 68 76 122 123 (online supplemental table S5). Studies have reported how a summary measure of multiple pollutants (NO2, PM2.5, PM10, NO2, SO2 and CO) is positively associated with ED visits or hospital admissions for asthma.26123126

We also acknowledge that in some multipollutant models, exposures subsume any association between PM or NO2 and asthma outcomes. A third weakness of our methodology is that with the exception of PM and NO,2 we were not able to undertake meta-analysis due to heterogeneity between measured exposures and reported asthma outcomes. A further weakness, we explained earlier is that our analysis was focused on the same age group and exposures as our previous review.4 And we acknowledge that dietary and respiratory viruses may not qualify as environment exposures as per WHO definition. We were also restricted to using the same tool for QA as in the earlier review which is not specific to one study design.

In conclusion, there is evidence of associations between many inhaled exposures, and exposure to a Mediterranean diet and worse asthma outcomes in children with established asthma. Future observational studies could usefully look at how exposures interact to trigger asthma symptoms, since in isolation many exposures are not uniformly associated with asthma outcomes. RCTs which deliver effective interventions in larger populations are required to determine the impact indoor air exposures in the home and at school have on asthma outcomes.

fn.p: Funding: The authors have not declared a specific grant for this research from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
Prepublication history and additional supplemental material for this paper are available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2024-091855).
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: All data relevant to the study are included in the article or uploaded as supplementary information.
